        that clear. ...Is some multi-cellular life form with stripes, huge 
        razor-sharp teeth, about eleven foot long, and of the genus Felis 
        Horribilis: what we doctors, in fact, call a 'tiger'.

name: AINSWORTH
text:
W-- Ah, well, it, uh,-- it has probably escaped 
        from a zoo. Mhm.

name: PAKENHAM-WALSH
text: Doesn't sound very likely to me.

name: SERGEANT
text:
Sir! Sir! Sir! The attack's over, sir! The Zulus are 
        retreating!

name: SERGEANT
text: Quite a lot of casualties, though, sir.

name: SERGEANT
text:
I should think about a hundred-- hundred and fifty 
        men altogether, sir.

name: SERGEANT
text:
I haven't got the final figures, sir, but there's a 
        lot of seriously...

name: AINSWORTH
text:
Yes. Well, the thing is, Sergeant, I've got a bit 
        of a problem here. One of the officers has lost a leg.

name: AINSWORTH
text: I'm afraid so. Probably a tiger.

name: AINSWORTH
text:
Stumm. Stumm. Stumm. The M.O. says we can stitch it 
        back on if we can find it immediately.

name: SERGEANT
text:
Right, sir! I'll organise a party... right away, 
        sir.

name: AINSWORTH
text:
Well, it's hardly the time for that, is it 
        Sergeant?

name: AINSWORTH
text: Oh! Oh! Ah! Ahh! Much better idea! Mhmm.

name: SERGEANT
text:
Oh, sorry about the mess, sir. We'll try and get it 
        cleared up by the time you get back.

name: SERGEANT
text: Here, we've got a search party. Leave that alone.

name: VICTIM #2
text:
This is fun, sir, isn't it? All this killing, 
        bloodshed-- Bloody good fun, sir, isn't it?

name: AINSWORTH
text: Nasty wound you've got there, Potter.

name: AINSWORTH
text: Come on, Private. We're making up a search party.

name: VICTIM #3
text:
Better than staying at home, isn't this, sir? Eh? I 
        mean, at home, if you kill someone, they arrest you. Here, they give you 
        a gun and show you what to do, sir.

name: VICTIM #3
text:
I mean, I killed fifteen of those buggers, sir. 
        Now, at home, they'd hang me! Here, they'll give me a fucking medal, 
        sir!

name: REAR END
text:
Uhh. Uh, don't shoot. Don't shoot. We're not a 
        tiger. W-- Uhh, we were jus-- s-- st, um,--

name: AINSWORTH
text: Why are you dressed as a tiger?

name: REAR END
text:
Hm? Oh, 'why'! 'Why'! 'Why'! Haahh, isn't it a 
        lovely day today?

name: FRONT END
text:
Well, uhh, actually, we're-- we're dressed like 
        this because, uh,-- Oh. No, that's not it.

name: REAR END
text:
Uh, we did it for a lark. Part of a spree. High 
        spirits, you know. Simple as that. Hm.

name: FRONT END
text:
Well, actually, we're on a mission for British 
        Intelligence. Th-- th-- there's a pro-Tsarist Ashanti Chief, uh,--

name: FRONT END
text: Uh, no. No, no, no. No. No. No.

name: REAR END
text:
No. No, no, no, no. No. No, we're doing it for an 
        advertisement.

name: FRONT END
text:
Uh, we're-- we're doing an advert for 'Tiger' brand 
        coffee.

name: REAR END
text:
'Tiger' brand coffee is a real treat. Even tigers 
        prefer a cup of it to real meat. Mm.

name: REAR END
text:
All right. All right. We are dressed as a tiger 
        because he had an auntie who did it in eighteen-thirty-nine, and this is 
        the fiftieth anniversary.

name: FRONT END
text: No. We're doing it for a bet.

name: REAR END
text: God told us to do it.

name: FRONT END
text: To tell the truth, we are completely mad.

name: FRONT END
text:
We are-- we are inmates of a Bengali psychiatric 
        institution and we escaped by making this skin out of old, used cereal 
        packets.

name: PERKINS
text:
It doesn't matter why they're dressed as a tiger. 
        Have they got my leg?

name: REAR END
text:
...it's because we were thinking of training as 
        taxidermists and we want to get the feel of it from the animal's point 
        of view.

name: AINSWORTH
text:
Be quiet. Now look. We're just asking you if you've 
        got this man's leg.

name: AINSWORTH
text:
No, no. A proper leg! Look. He was fast asleep, and 
        someone or something came in and removed it.

name: REAR END
text:
We found the tiger skin in a bicycle shop in Cairo. 
        The owner wanted it taken down to Dar Es Salaam--

name: AINSWORTH
text:
Shut up! Now look. Have you or have you not got his 
        leg?

name: FRONT END
text: No, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no, no.

name: REAR END
text: No, no, no. No. No. No. No.

name: FRONT END
text:
Oh, come on. I mean, do we look like the sort of 
        chaps who'd creep into a camp at night, steal into someone's tent, 
        anaesthetise them, tissue-type them, amputate a leg, and run away with 
        it?

name: FRONT END
text:
Oh, 'leg'! You're looking for a leg! Actually, I 
        think there is one in there somewhere. Uhh, somebody must have abandoned 
        it here, knowing you were coming after it, and we stumbled across it, 
        actually, and wondered what it was, and they'll be miles away by now,...

name: ZULU ANNOUNCER
text:
Hello. Good evening, and welcome to 'The 
        Middle of the Film'.

name: LADY PRESENTER
text:
Hello, and welcome to 'The Middle of the 
        Film', the moment where we take a break to invite you, the audience, to 
        join us, the film-makers, in 'Find the Fish'. We're going to show you a 
        scene from another film and ask you to guess where the fish is, but, if 
        you think you know, don't keep it to yourselves! Yell out so that all 
        the cinema can hear you. So, here we are with... 'Find the Fish'.

name: STRANGE MAN
text: I wonder where that fish has gone.

name: STRANGE WOMAN
text:
You did love it so. You looked after it like a 
        son.

name: STRANGE MAN
text: And it went wherever I did go.

name: STRANGE WOMAN
text:
Wouldn't you like to know? It was a lovely 
        little fish.

name: STRANGE MAN
text: And it went wherever I did go.

name: MAN IN AUDIENCE
text:
Have you thought of the drawers in the 
        bureau?!

name: STRANGE WOMAN
text: It is a most elusive fish!

name: STRANGE MAN
text: And it went wherever I did go.

name: STRANGE MAN
text: That went wherever I did go.

name: MAN IN AUDIENCE
text: Yeah, it's hidden in his trousers!

name: FISH #2
text:
They haven't said much about the meaning of life so 
        far, have they?

name: FISH #1
text: Well, it's been building up to it.

name: FISH #3
text: Yeah, I expect they'll get on to it now.

name: FISH #5
text:
Personally, I very much doubt if they're going to say 
        anything about the meaning of life at all.

name: FISH #6
text: Oh, come on. They've got to say something.

name: FISH #3
text: What do you think the next bit will be, then?

name: FISH #6
text:
What? About the next stage of life, you mean? Oh, 
        yeah. Here we go.

name: MR. MARVIN HENDY
text: Oh, that's much better. Thank you, honey.

name: MR. HENDY
text: Mmmm. It was all sort of misty before.

name: JOELINE
text: What kind of food 'd you like to eat this evening?

name: MR. HENDY
text: Well, we sort of like pineapples.

name: MR. HENDY
text:
Yeah, anything with pineapple in it is great for 
        us.

name: JOELINE
text: Mm. Well, how about the Dungeon Room?

name: JOELINE
text:
Sure is. It's real Hawaiian food served in an 
        authentic, medieval English dungeon atmosphere.

name: MR. HENDY
text:
Hmm m mm mm mmmm mm mm mmmm. Isn't this nice? Ha 
        hah. Why not? Good shot. Real Kodak. Oh! Thank you. Thank you very much. 
        Hm mm mmmm. Dah dah...

name: WAITER
text:
Good evening! Uhh, would you care for something to... 
        talk about?

name: WAITER
text:
Uh, that's, uh, 'football'. There you can talk about 
        the Steelers-Bears game this Saturday, or you could, uh, reminisce about 
        really great World Series.

name: WAITER
text:
Aah, no, it's more of an attempt to, uh, construct a 
        viable hypothesis to, uh, explain the meaning of life.

name: MR. HENDY
text:
Oh, that sounds wonderful. Would you like to talk 
        about the meaning of life, darling?

name: MR. HENDY
text: Yup. Uhh,-- uh, h-- how do we--

name: WAITER
text: Oh, uhh, you folks want me to start you off?

name: WAITER
text:
...look. Have you ever wondered... just why you're 
        here?

name: MR. HENDY
text:
Well, we went to Miami last year and California the 
        year before that, and we've--

name: WAITER
text:
No, no, no. I mean, uh, w-- why we're here... on this 
        planet.

name: WAITER
text:
Right! Aaah, you ever wanted to know what it's all 
        about?

name: WAITER
text: Right-o! Aah, well, uh, see, throughout history,...

name: WAITER
text:
...there have been certain men and women who have 
        tried to find the solution to the mysteries of existence,...

name: MRS. HENDY
text: And that's what we're talking about.

name: WAITER
text:
Well, you look like you're getting the idea, so why 
        don't I give you these, uh, conversation cards? They'll tell you a 
        little about philosophical method,...

name: WAITER
text:
...names of famous philosophers,-- Uh, there you are. 
        Uhh, have a nice conversation!

name: MR. HENDY
text: Oh, thank you. Thank you very much.

name: MRS. HENDY
text: Oh! I never knew Schopenhauer was a philosopher!

name: MR. HENDY
text: Oh, yeah! He's the one that begins with an 'S'.

name: MRS. HENDY
text:
Oh, wow. Yes, there is. Do all philosophers have 
        an 's' in them?

name: MR. HENDY
text: Uh, yeah! I think most of 'em do.

name: MRS. HENDY
text: Oh. Does that mean Selina Jones is a philosopher?

name: MR. HENDY
text:
Yeah! Right! She could be! She sings about the 
        meaning of life.

name: MRS. HENDY
text:
Yeah. That's right, but I don't think she writes 
        her own material.

name: MR. HENDY
text: No. Oh, maybe Schopenhauer writes her material.

name: MRS. HENDY
text:
He writes the lyrics. Burt just writes the tunes, 
        only now, he's married to Carole Bayer Sager.

name: MR. HENDY
text: Oh, waiter. This conversation isn't very good.

name: WAITER
text:
Oh, I'm sorry, sir! Uhh, we do have one today that's 
        not on the menu. It's sort of a specialty of the house, you know.

name: ANNOUNCER
text:
The Meaning of Life: Part Five: Live Organ 
        Transplants.

name: MAN
text: Hello. Uhh, can we have your liver?

name: MAN
text:
Your liver. It's a large, ehh, glandular organ in your 
        abdomen.

name: MAN
text:
You know, it's, uh,-- it's reddish-brown. It's sort of, 
        uhh,--

name: MR. BROWN
text:
Yeah,-- y-- y-- yeah, I know what it is, but... I'm 
        using it, eh.

name: MR. BROWN
text: Stop! Hey! Hey! Stop it. Hey!

name: MR. BROWN
text:
Listen! I can't give it to you now. It says, 'in 
        the event of death'. Uh. Oh! Ah. Ah. Eh.

name: MAN
text:
No one who has ever had their liver taken out by us has 
        survived.

name: ERIC
text: Just lie there, sir. It won't take a minute.

name: MAN
text: Uh, he's donating his liver, madam.

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
Is this because he took out one of those silly 
        cards?

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
He goes down to the public library, he sees a few 
        signs up, comes home all full of good intentions.

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
He gives blood. He does cold research. All that 
        sort of thing.

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
What do you, uh,-- what do you do with them all, 
        anyway?

name: ERIC
text: They all go to saving lives, madam.

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
Mmm. That's what he used to say. 'It's all for the 
        good of the country' he used to say.

name: MRS. BROWN
text: Do you think it's all for the good of the country?

name: MRS. BROWN
text: Do you think it's all for the good of the country?

name: MAN
text:
Well, I wouldn't know about that, madam. We're just, uh, 
        doing our jobs, you know.

name: YOUNG MAN
text:
Mum. Dad. I'm off out now. I'll see you about 
        seven.

name: MAN
text: Oh, well, that would be very nice.

name: MAN
text: Oh, eh,-- I thought she'd never ask.

name: MAN
text:
Uhh, you do realize, uh, he has to be, uh,... well, 
        dead,... by the terms of the card, uh, before he donates his liver.

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
Well, I told him that, but he never listens to me. 
        Silly man!

name: MAN
text:
Only I was wondering, ehh,... well, you know, what you 
        was thinking of doing after that. I mean,

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
I'm too old for that sort of thing. I'm past my 
        prime.

name: MAN
text: Not at all. You're a very attractive woman.

name: MRS. BROWN
text:
Well, I'm certainly not thinking of getting 
        hitched up again.

name: MAN
text: Can we have your liver, then?

name: MRS. BROWN
text: Yeah. All right. You talked me into it.

name: CHAIRMAN
text:
...Which brings us once again to the urgent 
        realization of just how much there is still left to own. Item six on the 
        agenda: the meaning of life. Now, uh, Harry, you've had some thoughts on 
        this.

name: HARRY
text:
That's right. Yeah, I've had a team working on this 
        over the past few weeks, and, uh, what we've come up with can be reduced 
        to two fundamental concepts. One: people are not wearing enough hats. 
        Two: matter is energy. In the universe, there are many energy fields 
        which we cannot normally perceive. Some energies have a spiritual source 
        which act upon a person's soul. However, this soul does not exist ab 
        initio, as orthodox Christianity teaches. It has to be brought into 
        existence by a process of guided self-observation. However, this is 
        rarely achieved, owing to man's unique ability to be distracted from 
        spiritual matters by everyday trivia.

name: BERT
text: What was that about hats, again?

name: HARRY
text: Oh, uh, people aren't wearing enough.

name: EDMUND
text:
Certainly. Hat sales have increased, but not pari 
        passu, as our research initially--

name: BERT
text: But when you say 'enough', enough for what purpose?

name: GUNTHER
text:
Can I just ask, with reference to your second point, 
        when you say souls don't develop because people become distracted,...

name: CHAIRMAN
text: Good Lord! The Crimson Permanent Assurance!

name: PROJECTIONIST
text:
We interrupt this film to apologise for this 
        unwarranted attack by the supporting feature. Luckily, we have been 
        prepared for this eventuality, and are now taking steps to remedy it.

name: ANNOUNCER
text: The Meaning of Life: Part Six: The Autumn Years.

name: NOL COWARD
text:
Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. Here's a 
        little number I tossed off recently in the Caribbean.

name: MAX
text: Oh, what a frightfully witty song.

name: MATRE D
text: Ah, good afternoon, sir, and how are we today?

name: MR. CREOSOTE
text: Better get a bucket. I'm going to throw up.

name: MATRE D
text:
Uh, Gaston! A bucket for monsieur. There you are, 
        monsieur.

name: MATRE D
text: Oh! Pardon. Gaston! A thousand pardons, monsieur.

name: MATRE D
text:
Now, zis afternoon, we have monsieur's favorite: ze 
        jugged hare. Ze hare is very high, and ze sauce is very rich with 
        truffles, anchovies, Grand Marnier, bacon, and cream. Thank you, Gaston.

name: MATRE D
text: Oh! Allow me. A new bucket for monsieur,...

name: MATRE D
text:
Uh, today we have, uh, for appetizers: Excuse me. 
        Mhmm. Uh, moules marinires, pt de foie gras, beluga caviar, eggs 
        Benedictine, tart de poireaux-- that's leek tart,-- frogs' legs 
        amandine, or oeufs de caille Richard Shepherd-- c'est  dire, little 
        quails' eggs on a bed of pured mushroom. It's very delicate. Very 
        subtle.

name: MATRE D
text:
A wise choice, monsieur. And now, how would you like 
        it served? All, uh, mixed up togezer in a bucket?

name: MR. CREOSOTE
text: Yeah,... with the eggs on top.

name: MATRE D
text: But of course, avec les oeufs frites.

name: MR. CREOSOTE
text: Yeah, and don't skimp on the pt.

name: MATRE D
text:
Oh, monsieur, I assure you, just because it is mixed 
        up wis all ze other things, we would not dream of giving you less than 
        ze full amount. In fact, I will personally make sure you have a double 
        helping. Maintenant quelque chose  boire. Something to drink, monsieur?

name: MR. CREOSOTE
text:
Yeah, I'll have six bottles of Chteau Latour 
        Forty-five...

name: MATRE D
text: Bon, and the usual brown ales?

name: MR. CREOSOTE
text:
Yeah. No, wait a minute. I think I can only 
        manage six crates today.

name: MATRE D
text: D'accord. Ah! Ze new bucket and ze cleaning woman.

name: MATRE D
text: Perhaps you're not... happy with the service?

name: GUEST #4'S WIFE
text:
It's just that we have to go. I'm having 
        rather a heavy period.

name: GUEST #4
text: And... we... have... a... train to catch.

name: GUEST #4'S WIFE
text:
Oh. Yes. Yes, of course. We have a train to 
        catch, and I don't want to start bleeding all over the seats. Ha, hm hm 
        hm.

name: MATRE D
text:
Oh! Very well, monsieur. Thank you so much. So nice 
        to see you, and I hope very much we will see you again very soon. Au 
        revoir, monsieur.

name: MATRE D
text: And finally, monsieur, a wafer-thin mint.

name: MATRE D
text: Oh, sir, it's only a tiny, little, thin one.

name: MR. CREOSOTE
text:
Look. I couldn't eat another thing. I'm 
        absolutely stuffed. Bugger off.

name: MATRE D
text: Thank you, sir, and now, here's ze check.

name: ANNOUNCER
text:
The Meaning of Life: Part Six B: The Meaning of 
        Life.

name: MATRE D
text:
M-hm-hmm. You know, Maria, I sometimes wonder if 
        we'll ever discover the meaning of it all working in a place like this.

name: MARIA
text:
Oh, I've worked in worse places, philosophically 
        speaking.

name: MARIA
text:
Yes. I used to work in the Acadmie Franaise, but it 
        didn't do me any good at all,

name: GASTON
text: As for me, huh, if you want to know what I think,

name: MATRE D
text: Ah! I was saying that-- Uh, allo?

name: GASTON
text:
This way. Come on. Don't be shy. Mind the stairs, all 
        right? I think this will help explain. Come along. Come along. Over 
        here. Come on. Come on.

name: ANNOUNCER
text: The Meaning of Life: Part Seven: Death.

name: NARRATOR #2
text:
This man is about to die. In a few moments, now, 
        he will be killed, for Arthur Jarrett is a convicted criminal who has 
        been allowed to choose the manner of his own execution.

name: GOVERNOR
text:
Arthur Charles Herbert Runcie MacAdam Jarrett, you 
        have been convicted by twelve good persons and true... of the crime of 
        first degree making of gratuitous, sexist jokes in a moving picture.

name: PADRE
text: Ashes to ashes, dust to dust.

name: GEOFFREY
text:
Yes, well, the thing is, we've got some people from 
        America for dinner tonight, and--

name: GEOFFREY
text:
It's a 'Mr. Death' or something. He's come about the 
        reaping? I don't think we need any at the moment.

name: ANGELA
text:
Hello. Well, don't leave him hanging around outside, 
        darling. Ask him in.

name: GEOFFREY
text: Darling, I don't think it's quite the moment.

name: ANGELA
text:
Do come in. Come along in. Come and have a drink. Do. 
        Come on.

name: ANGELA
text: It's one of the little men from the village.

name: ANGELA
text: This is Howard Katzenberg from Philadelphia...

name: ANGELA
text:
...and these are the Portland-Smythes, Jeremy and 
        Fiona.

name: ANGELA
text: Hardly surprising, in this weather. Ha ha ha.

name: HOWARD
text:
So, you still, uh, reap around here, do you, Mr. 
        Death?

name: DEBBIE
text:
We were just talking about some of the awful problems 
        facing the thir--

name: ANGELA
text:
Ohh. Would you prefer white? I-- I'm afraid we don't 
        have any beer.

name: GRIM REAPER
text: I am not of this world.

name: DEBBIE
text:
Well, isn't that extraordinary? We were just talking 
        about death only five minutes ago.

name: ANGELA
text: You know, whether death is really the end.

name: DEBBIE
text:
As my husband, uh, Howard, here, feels, or whether 
        there is-- and one so hates to use words like 'soul' or 'spirit', but--

name: JEREMY
text: But what other words can one use?

name: HOWARD
text: Let me just tell you something, Mr. Death.

name: HOWARD
text:
Just one moment. I'd like to express, on behalf of 
        everybody here, what a... really unique experience this is.

name: ANGELA
text:
Yes, we're so delighted, uh, that you dropped in, Mr. 
        Death.

name: DEBBIE
text: Mr. Death, is there an after-life?

name: HOWARD
text: Dear, if you could just wait, please, a moment,--

name: ANGELA
text: Are you sure you wouldn't like some sherry?

name: HOWARD
text:
Angela. Angela, I'd like to just say this at this 
        time, if I could, please. Really.

name: HOWARD
text: Can I just say this at this time, please?

name: GRIM REAPER
text: Silence! I have come for you.

name: GRIM REAPER
text: Take you away. That is my purpose. I am death.

name: GEOFFREY
text:
Well, that's cast rather a gloom over the evening, 
        hasn't it?

name: HOWARD
text: I don't see it that way, Geoff.

name: GRIM REAPER
text:
Shut up! Shut up, you American. You always talk, 
        you Americans. You talk and you talk and say 'let me tell you something' 
        and 'I just wanna say this'. Well, you're dead now, so shut up!

name: GEOFFREY
text:
Now, look here. You barge in here, quite uninvited, 
        break glasses, and then announce, quite casually, that we're all dead. 
        Well, I would remind you that you are a guest in this house, and--

name: GRIM REAPER
text:
Be quiet! Englishmen, you're all so fucking 
        pompous, and none of you have got any balls.

name: DEBBIE
text: Can I ask you a question?

name: DEBBIE
text: How can we all have died at the same time?

name: GEOFFREY
text: Darling, you didn't use canned salmon, did you?

name: GRIM REAPER
text: Now the time has come. Follow. Follow me.

name: ANGELA
text:
Well, the fishmonger promised me he'd have some fresh 
        salmon, and he's normally so reliable.

name: DEBBIE
text: Hey, I didn't even eat the mousse.

name: ANGELA
text:
Honestly, darling, I'm so embarrassed. It really is 
        embarrassing. I mean,...

name: ANGELA
text:
...to serve salmon with botulism at a dinner party is 
        social death for me.

name: JEREMY
text: Uh, shall we take our cars?

name: RECEPTIONIST
text:
Hello. Welcome to Heaven. Excuse me, could you 
        just sign here, please, sir?

name: RECEPTIONIST
text:
Thank you! There's a table for you through there 
        in the restaurant.

name: RECEPTIONIST
text:
Of course, madam. It's Christmas every day in 
        Heaven.

name: TONY BENNETT
text:
Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. It's truly a 
        real honorable experience to be here this evening, a very wonderful and 
        warm and emotional moment for all of us, and I'd like to sing a song for 
        all... of you.

name: LADY PRESENTER
text:
Well, that's the end of the film. Now, here's 
        the meaning of life. Thank you, Brigitte. M-hmm. Well, it's nothing very 
        special. Uh, try and be nice to people, avoid eating fat, read a good 
        book every now and then, get some walking in, and try and live together 
        in peace and harmony with people of all creeds and nations, and, 
        finally, here are some completely gratuitous pictures of penises to
